newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH GOVERNMENT SEEN STUDYING NESTE-IVO MERGER.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH GOVERNMENT SEEN STUDYING NESTE-IVO MERGER.

text.p: A cautiously worded statement by the Finnish ministry of trade and industry about studying the joint development of state-owned power groups Neste Oy and Imatran Voima Oy (IVO) led to merger speculation on Tuesday.
The ministry said in a statement it would undertake a review to "evaluate the options for broadening the shareholder base and the structural alternatives for joint development of the two companies."
It referred to oil, chemicals and energy group Neste and power producer IVO.

The state owns 84 percent of Neste and all of IVO. A partial floatation of IVO has been expected. The government has an authorisation by parliament to cut its stakes in both companies to 50.1 percent.
"Neste and IVO together have core competencies across the whole energy chain," Neste said in a statement.

"The combined strengths of the companies will offer maximum access to growth opportunities in the Nordic region, Russia and the Baltic area and will allow a significant position to be built in the gas and electricity markets of North and central Europe," it said.
Neste President Jukka Viinanen told Reuters by telephone that a merger was one option under investigation.
"Our perception is that a merger is one option being investigated here," he said. "We feel it would be good for shareholders," he added.
Asked what other options than a merger would be studied, Viinanen gave no details but said: "what point would there be in a context of this scale to create smaller units?"
IVO CEO Heikki Marttinen said he saw some potential synergies from a merger.
"I believe that there could be synergies in some areas, but also there are clearly areas where there would not be," he said.
Underlining they had hardly any facts to rely on, share analysts took a cautiously positive approach.

"A merger can certainly not be ruled out although the operations of the groups' operations differ so much," said Visa Manninen, analyst at Carnegie Securities, adding it was unusual to merge an oil and a nuclear power company.
Aktia Bank analyst Henry Kallio said the owners' intention was probably to create a stronger entity. "One can safely discount a bigger cashflow for Neste in the future," he said.
"This is positive for Neste ... future earnings expectations can be improved," he said.
But Aktia's neutral recommendation on Neste would stand since "we have nothing concrete yet," Kallio added.
Neste's Viinanen said combining IVO and Neste would create a bigger group than Swedish Vattenfall, but it would remain smaller than Norsk Hydro and some German rivals measured by assets.
At end-1996, Neste's balance sheet total was 31.6 billion markka and IVO's 28.2 billion. Neste's 1996 net sales were 43.4 billion markka asnd IVO's 12.1 billion.
The ministry's review is scheduled to be completed by the end of August.

Neste's share initially rose when trade started after a suspension pending the afternoon announcement. It hit a 15-week high 145.00 markka, up 7.00 markka or five percent, but later closed at 138.50 markka, up 0.50.
